abstract.p: There is widespread interest in using various statistical inference tools as a part of the evaluations for individual teachers and schools. Evaluation systems typically involve classifying hundreds or even thousands of teachers or schools according to their estimated performance. Many current evaluations are largely based on individual estimates and hypothesis tests, with little or no consideration of controlling simultaneous error rates and their potential effect on the whole educational evaluation system. In this article, we discuss controlling simultaneous errors in classification of teachers or schools by a decision-theoretic approach. We first develop a β-mixture model to estimate the local false discovery rate (local fdr) by the classic p-values from one-sided tests. We discuss a few decision rules based on standard loss functions. We also construct a controversy loss function to further accommodate the incoherence between effect size and local fdr. We apply the proposed approach to evaluate adequate yearly progress (AYP) in math proficiency of Pennsylvania schools.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is widespread interest in using student achievement data and value-added measures to evaluate the performance of individual educators such as teachers and schools for accountability. Evaluations based on student achievements are the capstone of many federal and state education policies (Gordon, Kane, & Staiger, 2006; Podgursky & Springer, 2007).

Evaluation systems based on these measures typically involve identifying schools or teachers with effective practices, for example, schools and teachers that make adequate yearly progress (AYP), or have value-added scores that are clearly above average or exceed a standard such as the growth standard used in the Pennsylvania Value-Added Assessment System (PVAAS). These classifications can involve simultaneous decisions for hundreds or even thousands of teachers or schools. Each decision is subject to error that could result in misclassifying teachers or schools as exceeding the threshold when they do not or vice versa. Statistical one-sided hypothesis tests are a common approach to controlling the probability of misclassification for each individual decision. However, the collection of errors in the whole evaluation system must also be of concern to stakeholders. At the system level, the entire collection of classifications determines whether scarce resources are well-allocated or whether the data are useful for other types of decision making. Hence, the simultaneous inference problem is important for education policymakers and administrators. In this article, we address the pressing issue of simultaneous statistical inference in large-scale education evaluation systems.

There are several statistical methods to control the rate or occurrences of false positive findings in simultaneous inference. Early examples include the Bonferroni and Sidak adjustments (Miller, 1977), which control the familywise error rate (FWER). More recent developments have focused on controlling the less stringent false discovery rate (FDR) defined as the expected proportion of Type I errors made among all positive findings (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995). For instance, guideline 5-1-4A in the 2002 Statistical Standards of the National Center for Education Statistics suggests FDR as the basis of adjustment in multiple comparisons. However, these methods as currently implemented are not appropriate for educational evaluations, because they emphasize false positive errors and do not sufficiently consider the potential for false negative errors. For example, when the goal of evaluation is to identify high performers, a false negative error occurs when high-performing teachers or schools fail to be recognized. Performance-based pay and accountability systems are meant to motivate changes in performance by recognizing especially good- or poor-performing teachers or schools. It is clear that both false positive errors (e.g., reward undeserving teachers) and false negative errors (e.g., fail to reward truly high performers) can weaken the motivational power of such a system. Unlike most other applications involving simultaneous inference, false positive errors are not necessarily the dominating concern in many education evaluation systems.

Many education evaluations are based on one-sided hypothesis tests. For example, the 2007 Pennsylvania Consolidated State Application Accountability Workbook specifies that the failure to make AYP by a school is determined by one-sided z-tests. Previous work in simultaneous inference was motivated by applications focusing on two-sided hypotheses. In a later section, we discuss in more details the modeling difference between two-sided and one-sided hypotheses.

Based on the concept of local fdr introduced in Efron, Tibshirani, Storey, and Tusher (2001), we develop a decision-theoretic approach to simultaneous inference in education evaluation systems. Our approach consists of two steps. First, we propose a β-mixture model to estimate the local fdr from the one-sided p-values for testing the effectiveness of each individual school or teacher. Second, we discuss several Bayesian decision rules to control and balance some suitable measures of errors in large-scale simultaneous inference.

This article is organized as follows. The next section briefly reviews the theoretical framework of simultaneous inference and the local fdr concept. We then discuss in detail a β-mixture model for estimating local fdr. A simulation study is also presented to demonstrate the performance of the proposed β-mixture model. We further discuss several Bayesian decision rules for simultaneous inference. In particular, we propose the controversy loss function to balance effect size and two types of inference errors. The β-mixture model and Bayesian decision rules are applied to an example of evaluating yearly progress in math proficiency of Pennsylvania public schools. The article concludes with a brief discussion. The appendix provides additional technical details referenced in the text.

sec.title: The Basic Error Measures in Simultaneous Inference
sec.p: This section briefly introduces the theoretical framework of simultaneous inference. For clarity, we define decisions in terms of schools but the concepts apply to teachers equally. A school is associated with several important quantities: a quantitative school effect θ, a qualitative effect H, and an evaluation decision D.

A comprehensive review of modeling approaches for θ can be found in McCaffrey, Han, and Lockwood (2009) and Harris and McCaffrey (2010). An example of simple estimators for θ is the average of students' gain scores (current score less the prior year score).

The qualitative effect H is a hypothesis about the unknown true effectiveness of a school, for example, a school succeeds or fails to make AYP. H is naturally defined as a dichotomous constant indicator that the one-sided null hypothesis is true. For instance, H can be defined to differentiate positive effectiveness (H = 0 or θ > c) from ineffectiveness (H = 1 or θ ≤ c), where the constant c is referred to as the threshold defining the null hypothesis. For example, c can be 0 meaning that any positive (or negative) effectiveness should be acknowledged. The threshold c will depend on evaluation purposes and selectivity.

The evaluation decision D is the conclusion about H. We define D = 1 as rejecting the null hypothesis. When the goal is to identify high-performing schools, the null hypothesis is H = I {θ ≤ c}, where I is the indicator function. D = 1 means rejecting the null hypothesis, namely, awarding a school. In the opposite setting to identify low-performing schools, H = I {θ ≥ c}, and D = 1 implies we concluded θ < c. D is essentially the statistical test associated with the null hypothesis H.

We use the same notations with subscripts Hi , Di , θ i , i = 1 … N to denote the quantities of individual schools, where N is the total number of schools being evaluated. We also call the indices with Hi = 1 the null cases and the indices with Hi = 0 the nonnull cases.

sec.title: A β-Mixture Model for Estimating Local fdr
sec.p: Existing approaches to estimating the empirical distribution of p-values and local fdr are usually based on some form of (1), for example, Efron et al. (2001), Pounds and Morris (2003), Do, Muller, and Tang (2005). Without any additional restrictions on f 0 and f 1, (1) is not identified. Namely, for a given likelihood f(x), the choice of f 0 and f 1 is not unique. For example, we can always switch the definition of πf 0 and (1 – π)f 1 without changing the likelihood. However, in two-sided tests (θ = c vs θ ≠ c) and if the summary statistic x is the regular p-value, f 0 is the uniform distribution U(0,1) and (1) is identified. In this case, only the mixture density f and the mixing proportion π need to be estimated in order to estimate the local fdr. When f 0 is unknown but π ≈ 1, almost all large p-values are sampled from f 0 (e.g., if π = .9 then almost all p-values greater than .6 are sampled from f 0) and by restricting to these values f 0 can also be estimated (Efron, 2007; Langaas, Lindqvist, & Ferkingstad, 2005).

Nevertheless, neither of these approaches will work with many education applications. First, as noted above, many education evaluation applications focus on testing one-sided null hypotheses, for example, H = I {θ ≤ c} for identifying high-performing schools. For one-sided tests, the density for p-values of null cases f 0 is unknown and can be very different from the uniform density of two-sided tests. Second, in education applications, the proportion of schools of interest π (i.e., the proportion of schools above or below the threshold c) can range from a small value to moderately large, depending on the purpose of the evaluation. Due to these difficulties, the existing empirical Bayesian methods are not suitable for the one-sided p-values from education evaluations.

For one-sided p-values, one would expect large p-values for the null cases and small p-values for the nonnull cases. This intuition suggests that the density of null cases f 0(p) may be increasing in p. Alternatively, p-values should tend to be small for the nonnull cases, so that f 1 may be decreasing in p. The following proposition formalizes this intuition:
Proposition 1: For an individual member of the sample, that is, teacher or school, let g θ(z) be the density of the test statistic z for a given value of θ. If the family of densities g θ, as indexed by θ, satisfies the monotone likelihood ratio (MLR) criterion, then the density of p-values is increasing in p for null cases and decreasing for nonnull cases.
Detailed developments of Proposition 1 are in the appendix. A family of densities g θ satisfies the MLR criterion if for every θ2 > θ1,

sec.title: Simulations
sec.p: In this section, we numerically verify the performance of the β-mixture model (3) in approximating the local fdr. The purpose of the simulation study is first to examine the closeness of local fdr estimates based on the β-mixture (3) to the true local fdr, and second, to study the computational performance of the numerical optimizer ConstrOptim in fitting (3). To achieve these goals, we did not generate data directly from (3). Instead, we set up two data-generating scenarios mimicking typical educational evaluation systems. Educational evaluations have different goals, for example, we would expect a large percentage of schools with AYP, and a small percentage of teachers with outstanding teaching effectiveness. We designed the two scenarios corresponding to these two typical settings. We added another two scenarios similar to the common simulation settings in two-sided tests. None of the true densities in any scenario follows (3). However, we expect that the local fdr estimator based on the β-mixture model can still retain good performance, due to the flexibility of the β distribution. Without loss of generality, in all scenarios, we used the threshold c = 0 and tested the one-sided alternative hypothesis 0 > c. For simplicity, we fixed the sample size per unit or estimation error within each scenario.

sec.title: Bayesian Decision Rules for Simultaneous Inference
sec.p: In this section, we discuss several Bayesian decision rules suitable for the applications in education evaluation systems. The existing literature based on p-value adjustments focuses on controlling Type I error rates, for example, FDR. However, for many education evaluations the popular FDR-controlling decision rules which emphasize limiting Type I errors may be inappropriate, and decision rules that balance both types of errors may be preferred. Due to the difference in the purposes of various evaluation systems, it is difficult to apply a single decision rule to all cases. Below, we discuss several decision-theoretic approaches. Specifically, we first briefly review the standard decision rules based on a cutoff on local fdr. Next, we propose a new loss function, the controversy loss, which can combine the effect size and local fdr into a unified decision-making procedure.

sec.title: Decision Rules Based on Local fdr
sec.p:
Most of the recently developed decision rules for multiple testing are FDR control rules. Analogous to classic hypothesis tests, which are designed to yield the smallest Type II error probability while constraining Type I error below a bound, the FDR control rules also attempt to be “most powerful” by providing rules that yield the most rejections, while keeping the FDR below a specified bound. Based on the local fdr, the optimal decision rule is straightforward. First, we order the hypotheses by increasing local fdr. We then find the largest R such that

The nominal FDR level a and the ordered r (i) jointly determine the cutoff r (R). This rule meets the constraint on FDR because FDR equals the average local fdr of the rejected hypotheses, FDR = Σ iDiri /R (Han, Arnold, & Altman, 2009).

As previously discussed, Type I errors are not necessarily the emphasis in educational evaluations, and a balanced error measure, such as the Bayesian expected loss function, which explicitly combines the consequences of both types of errors, is preferable for these applications. Given a Bayesian expected loss function, the optimal decision rule is defined as the rule that minimizes the chosen loss function. This decision rule will then naturally limit both types of errors in accordance with the cost of each type. In the remainder of the article, we use the short term loss to refer to the Bayesian expected loss function.

A commonly used loss is the constant loss, which assumes that the consequences of a particular type of error are constant. The constant k is important in the local fdr control. Ideally, the choice of k should be determined by the real-world consequence of different types of errors. However, knowledge of such consequences may be unknown or difficult to quantify. Heuristically, we can borrow the notion of power analysis to help us determine an appropriate value for k. Recall that in the usual power analysis, the significance level α is usually a small number between .01 and .1, and the power β is usually between .5 and .9. Roughly speaking, the ratio of (1 – β)/α reflects our willingness to commit a Type II error as opposed to a Type I error. For the constant loss, k measures the severity of the consequences of a Type I error relative to those of a Type II error. If the willingness to commit a type of error is inversely proportional to the consequence of such an error, then k conceptually measures the quantity similar as (1 – β)/α. For most commonly used values of α and β, the cutoff on local fdr is usually larger than α. For example, when α = .05 and β = .8, the corresponding k is 4 and the local fdr cutoff is r 0 = .2. Using these notions, common choices for k are 19, 9, and 4, corresponding to local fdr cutoffs .05, .1, and .2, respectively.

The proportion of true null hypotheses, π, might also influence the choice of k. A large value of π indicates that many null cases are present, and therefore a rejection decision should be more cautious. sec.title: Decision Rules Adjusting for Effect Size
sec.p: Decision rules based on the constant loss function assume that the consequences of errors of the same type are equally undesirable regardless of the parameter estimates. However, this assumption is rarely a good approximation of the reality (Berger, 1985). For instance, when sample sizes and estimation errors are unequal among tests, as is common in applications, a trivial effect with very small estimation error may be associated with a smaller p-value than a large effect with relatively large estimation error. The trivial effect always has priority to be detected by the decision rules specifying a local fdr cutoff. Measures for schools and teachers linking to large numbers of students have smaller estimation error. Consequently, some of them will have an unfair advantage to be identified, if we use constant loss to determine our decision rule. Decision rules controlling FDR or the constant loss cannot address this difficulty.

The monotone Property 3 is a natural property that a sensible decision rule should possess: As either the local fdr decreases, or the estimated effect size increases, the decision will tend to be a rejection. A proof of property 3 is given in the appendix.

The controversy loss Lct requires three tuning constants. The role of k is the same as in the constant loss, and hence can be selected similarly. Recall that v defines a minimal distance between two effects such that a controversy can occur. In a practical evaluation system, a good sense of the least meaningful difference is often available. For these cases, v should be set accordingly. For instance, if we wish to classify a school on the basis of the percentage of students who score proficient on the state’s mathematics exam, a difference between schools of 1 percentage point may be considered inconsequential and we can set v ≈ .01.

sec.title: Numerical Comparisons of Decision Rules
sec.p: We used simulated data to compare the performance of proposed decision rules and methods with existing methods that have the same or similar goals.

We first examined the FDR control using the simulation data in the previous section. Our approach to FDR control uses Equation 7 and r(p) estimated from the β-mixture model (3). We compared our approach with the standard step-up method (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) on the 200 simulation datasets from each scenario under the same control level FDR ≤ .05. For each scenario, we used the sample mean of the 200 observed V/R ratios to measure the performance. The step-up method has mean V/R =.037, .010, .021, and .025 in the four scenarios, respectively. For comparisons, our approach has mean V/R =.052, .013, .014, and .051. In Scenarios 1, 2, and 4, our approach achieves the nominal FDR level better than the step-up method, and consequently yielded 24, 63, and 169 more detections. In the third scenario, both approaches have very few rejections due to the weak signals in nonnull cases (mean count of rejections R ≈ .2 for both approaches), and the difference in the two approaches is not practically meaningful. This finding is consistent with the results of Han et al. (2009), which found Bayesian FDR control also improves detection capability than the step-up method in two-sided tests.

We next examined the local fdr control, that is, minimizing Lk . Recall that the local fdr control is a cutoff of r(p), that is, D = I {r(p) ≤ 1 / (k + 1)}, where r(p) can be estimated by model (3). Alternatively, Efron (2007) used the inverse z-transformed p-values and a mixture of exponential family distributions to estimate r(p). We compared the performance of local fdr control based on these two methods for estimating r(p) with k = 4, that is, controlling r(p) ≤ .2. Since Efron’s method requires a large proportion of null cases with θ = 0, we only used the last two simulation scenarios in the previous section. Efron’s method had difficulties in fitting f 0 in some of the datasets. Whenever this happens, we used the theoretical null N(0,1) for f 0. The sample means of the 200 counts of correct rejections S are 13 and 769 for our method, and 2 and 638 for the comparison method, for the two scenarios, respectively. The improvement is solely due to model (3), which can readily handle p-values from one-sided tests without assuming a predominantly large π2.

sec.title: Analysis of Pennsylvania School Performance Data
sec.p: In this section, we apply the proposed empirical Bayesian method to evaluate the percentages of math proficiency for Pennsylvania public schools. A student’s math proficiency is determined by the state standardized math test. Proficient equals the minimum level of academic performance that all students are expected to attain under the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB). This consistent definition of proficiency makes the percentages of proficiency in different years directly comparable. Percentages of students scoring proficient or above based on the Pennsylvania System of School Assessment (PSSA) were reported to the public for each school by grade and subject. We retrieved the Pennsylvania school data from http://www.schooldatadirect.org. In this article, we focus on the math proficiency of Grades 6 through 8 in the school years 2006–2007 and 2007–2008. We excluded those sixth grade students in elementary schools and included only schools with some students in Grades 7 and 8. We had 822 and 833 schools in 2006–2007 and 2007–2008, respectively, among which 809 schools had records in both years. In 2006–2007, the mean number of students tested per school is 411 and the range is from 26 to 1485. The estimated percentages of math proficiency range from 9% to 100% The standard errors range from 0 to .08 with the average .027. In 2007–2008, the mean number of students tested per school is 398 and the range is from 34 to 1587. The estimated percentages of math proficiency range from 10% to 99%. The median percentages of proficiency are 69% and 71% for 2006–2007 and 2007–2008, respectively. The standard errors range from .4% to 8%, with the average 2.7%. The progress ranges from –20.1% to 38.7%, with the average 2.9%.

According to the Pennsylvania Consolidated State Application Accountability Workbook, a school’s math AYP is determined by a pair of one-sided tests. The first tests at α = .05, and the null hypothesis that the percentage of proficient students exceeds the annual threshold, Hi : θ i ≥ c, where c is the AYP threshold and θ i is the percentage of math proficiency of the ith school. The thresholds are 45% for 2006–2007 and 56% for 2007–2008 according to Pennsylvania Department of Education. The second tests at α = .25, and the null hypothesis that the percentage of nonproficiency decreased from the previous year by at least 10%. Let θ1,i and θ2,i denote the percentages of math proficiency in the 2 years. The null hypothesis is Hi : δθ i = θ2,i – .9θ1,i ≥ .1. This second test is referred to as the “safe harbor” criterion. If we fail to reject either null, a school is classified as meeting AYP. That is, a school fails to meet AYP only when we reject both hypotheses.

We conducted three sets of hypothesis tests for 2006–2007, 2007–2008, and the safe harbor evaluations, separately. For the yearly evaluations, the null hypothesis is Hi : θ i ≥ c, where c is the AYP threshold and θ i is the percentage of math proficiency of the ith school. The thresholds are 45% for 2006–2007 and 56% for 2007–2008 according to Pennsylvania Department of Education. For the safe harbor evaluations, let θ1,i and θ2,i denote the percentages of math proficiency in the 2 years. The null hypothesis is Hi : δθ i = θ2,i – .9θ1,i ≥ .1.

We fit three β-mixture models (3) to the three sets of one-sided p-values for 2006–2007 evaluations, 2007–2008 evaluations, and the safe harbor evaluations, separately. In fitting the β-mixture model, we used 10 sets of random initial values to run the numerical optimizer constrOptim. Most initial values yield very close fitting results. Among the results, we selected the one with the highest likelihood. We plotted the estimated local fdr versus the p-value on the left frame of Figure 2 . The right frame of Figure 2 presents the estimated densities f, πf 0, and (1 – π)f 1 in the safe harbor evaluations.

We applied the local fdr control, that is, the constant loss function Lk , to identify schools below AYP threshold in the two yearly evaluations. We used the local fdr control with k = 9 (approximately corresponding to α = .05 and β = .55), and made 94 rejections in 2006–2007 and 121 rejections for 2007–2008. For comparisons, had the local fdr not controlled for simultaneous inference, the individual tests at the regular significance level .05 would have yielded 107 and 131 rejections for the two yearly evaluations, respectively. The left panel in Figure 2 shows that the local fdr at p = .05 or p = .25 is large. Hence, the additional rejections made by the individual .05-level tests may be Type I errors. These two yearly evaluations contain few controversies. Thus, we did not apply the controversy loss.

In the safe harbor evaluations, there are many weak signals close to the threshold. Consequently, the local fdr control will yield many controversies. We applied the controversy loss Lct to reduce the total number of controversies. The original test on safe harbor standard is quite liberal (α = .25). We also set k = 2 to relax the local fdr cutoff accordingly. We tried a few typical values of r 0 and some small values for υ. Table 4 summarizes the decisions. Figure 1 presents the decisions for two choices of tuning constants (k* and υ). In this case r(.5) = 1. Based on the preceding discussion, we finally chose k* = .5 (1 + k) – 1 = .5 and υ = .02, which is the right frame in Figure 1.

Recall the final AYP status for 2007–2008 is determined by combining the decisions of the annual and safe harbor evaluations. Using the simultaneous inference tools above, we identified 40 schools that failed in both measures. For comparison, the decisions without adjusting simultaneous inference determined a total of 59 schools that failed to meet AYP. Further examining the 19 schools not rejected after adjusting simultaneous inference, we found that they have moderately large sample sizes (ranging from 100 to 600 for each year). For two-sample z-tests, such sample sizes can result in detections of very small effects. In fact, 13 of these 19 schools had an increase in the percentages of math proficiency between the two school years. Among the other six schools, five schools had a negligible decline (less than 1% in the percentage of math proficiency). Presumably, the simultaneous inference tools may have reduced the instances of Type I errors in 2007–2008 annual evaluations, and have limited the controversies in the safe harbor evaluations.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this article we present an empirical Bayesian approach to address the simultaneous inference issue in educational evaluations. Our approach first estimates the local fdr from one-sided p-values using a β-mixture model. We discuss a few decision rules based on some expected loss functions. The controversy loss is particularly suitable for educational evaluations since it combines the probability of making errors and the estimated effect size. Using the controversy loss Lct arguably overcomes the dilemma between the local fdr and the estimated effect size. The controversy loss Lct is preferred when there is large variation in estimation errors among test statistics, a case not uncommon in education evaluations.

The case study demonstrates the application of simultaneous inference tools. The β-mixture model offers the useful estimates, including the local fdr and the estimated proportions of each mixing component. The local fdr control can reduce the instances of Type I errors and balance the instances of Type II errors in annual evaluations. The safe harbor evaluation applies the controversy loss Lct to further take into consideration the difference in effect sizes.

Extensions of the current work may further investigate the potential dependence among data and the impact on decisions. The controversy loss is not limited to the β-mixture model, but can be readily applied to other empirical Bayesian and full Bayesian models for simultaneous inference.
